level.heading: APPLICANTS EDUCATED OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES (§ 17-8203)

level.text: The Board may grant a license to practice as a physical therapist assistant to an applicant who has been educated outside of the United States if the applicant:

Provides proof from the Physical Therapist Assistant Educational Equivalency Review (PTA-EER) that the applicant’s education is substantially equivalent to the requirements of physical therapist assistants educated in an education program accredited in the United States;
Passes the Board-approved English proficiency examination, if the applicant’s native language is not English; and
Complies with the examination requirements of Section 8204.
A determination that the applicant’s education is “substantially equivalent” shall include the following findings:
The applicant graduated from a physical therapist assistant education program that prepares the applicant to engage without restriction in the practice of physical therapist assistance;
Written proof that the applicant’s school is recognized by its own ministry of education or equivalent governmental authority; and

Completion of a credentials evaluation as directed by a credentialing board or equivalent body that determines the candidate has met uniform criteria for educational requirements as further established by rule.
